**Proof Outline Using the Minimal Polynomial Criterion**

Recall that over a field \(F\) (say, \(\mathbb{C}\) or \(\mathbb{R}\)), a linear operator \(T: V \to V\) on a finite-dimensional vector space \(V\) is diagonalizable if and only if its **minimal polynomial** over \(F\) splits completely into **distinct linear factors** (i.e., no repeated roots).

1. **Minimal Polynomial of \(T\):**  
   Since \(V\) is finite-dimensional, \(T\) has a characteristic polynomial \(\chi_T(x)\) and a minimal polynomial \(\mu_T(x)\). The minimal polynomial divides the characteristic polynomial and has the property that \(\mu_T(T) = 0\). Moreover, \(T\) is diagonalizable if and only if \(\mu_T(x)\) is a product of distinct linear factors (i.e., no repeated roots).

2. **Dual Operator \(T'\):**  
   Define the dual space \(V^* = \mathrm{Hom}(V, F)\). The dual operator \(T': V^* \to V^*\) is given by
   \[
     (T'(f))(v) \;=\; f\bigl(T(v)\bigr) 
     \quad\text{for all }f \in V^*,\,v \in V.
   \]
   Equivalently, \(T'(f) = f \circ T\).

3. **Minimal Polynomial of \(T'\) is the Same:**  
   - We claim that \(T'\) satisfies precisely the **same** minimal polynomial as \(T\). Indeed, if \(\mu_T(x)\) is the minimal polynomial of \(T\), then \(\mu_T(T) = 0\). Because the same polynomial relation carries over to the dual (you can check this by applying \(\mu_T(T')\) to an arbitrary \(f \in V^*\)), it follows that \(\mu_T(T') = 0\). 
   - Hence, the minimal polynomial of \(T'\) divides \(\mu_T(x)\). Conversely, one also checks that any polynomial annihilating \(T'\) would have to annihilate \(T\), giving us equality of minimal polynomials. Therefore
     \[
       \mu_{T'}(x) \;=\; \mu_T(x).
     \]

4. **Equivalence of Diagonalizability:**  
   - Since \(\mu_{T'}(x) = \mu_T(x)\), the minimal polynomials of \(T\) and \(T'\) have the **same roots and same factorization** in \(F[x]\).  
   - Consequently, \(T\) is diagonalizable \(\Longleftrightarrow\) \(\mu_T(x)\) splits into distinct linear factors \(\Longleftrightarrow\) \(\mu_{T'}(x)\) also splits into distinct linear factors \(\Longleftrightarrow\) \(T'\) is diagonalizable.

Hence, **\(T\) is diagonalizable if and only if \(T'\) is diagonalizable.**

---

### An Alternative Geometric Sketch (Optional)

Another way to see this (more geometrically) is to use the fact that if \(T\) is diagonalizable, then \(V\) decomposes as a direct sum of its eigenspaces:
\[
  V \;=\; \bigoplus_{\lambda} E_\lambda(T),
\]
where \(E_\lambda(T) = \{\,v \in V : T(v) = \lambda v\,\}\). One then considers the induced action on the dual space \(V^*\). It turns out that the dual space decomposes correspondingly into generalized eigenspaces (and if the operator is already diagonalizable, these are actual eigenspaces). This sets up a direct correspondence between the eigen-decomposition of \(T\) on \(V\) and that of \(T'\) on \(V^*\).

But the most succinct proof uses the **minimal polynomial** argument given above.

parts:
First, let us clarify the question properly:

- A linear operator \(T\) on a complex inner‐product space \(\,V\) is called _unitarily diagonalizable_ if there is an orthonormal basis of \(V\) (or equivalently a unitary matrix \(U\)) in which the matrix of \(T\) is diagonal.  Equivalently, \(T\) is unitarily diagonalizable exactly when \(T\) is a **normal** operator, i.e.\ \(T T^* = T^* T\).

- The _dual operator_ \(T'\) is the induced operator on the dual space \(V^*\) defined by 
  \[
    (T'(f))(v) \;=\; f\bigl(T(v)\bigr),\quad \forall\,f\in V^*,\,v\in V.
  \]
  In coordinates (with respect to the usual dual basis), the matrix of \(T'\) is simply the **transpose** of the matrix of \(T\), not the adjoint.

The question is:

> **Are there examples of a (complex) linear operator \(T\) that is unitarily diagonalizable (i.e.\ normal) but whose dual operator \(T'\) is *not* unitarily diagonalizable (i.e.\ not normal)?**

The short (and somewhat surprising) answer is **no**—there are _no_ such counterexamples. Whenever \(T\) is normal, its transpose \(T^\top\) (which is the matrix that represents \(T'\) in the dual basis) also turns out to be normal. Consequently, \(T'\) is itself unitarily diagonalizable if \(T\) is.

---

## Why \(T\) Normal Implies \(T^\top\) Is Also Normal

Let us spell out why the transpose of a normal matrix is again normal (over the complex field). Recall:

- A matrix \(M\in M_{n}(\mathbb{C})\) is **normal** if and only if \(M M^\dagger = M^\dagger M\).  
  Here \(M^\dagger = \overline{M}^{\,T}\) is the usual (conjugate) adjoint.

- The dual operator \(T':V^*\to V^*\) in coordinates is \(T^\top\), meaning \(\operatorname{Mat}(T') = (\operatorname{Mat}(T))^\top\).

Hence to show \(T'\) is normal exactly when \(T\) is normal, one needs to check that
\[
  \bigl(T^\top \bigr)\bigl(T^\top\bigr)^\dagger 
  \;=\; \bigl(T^\top\bigr)^\dagger \bigl(T^\top\bigr),
\]
whenever \(T\) itself satisfies \(T\,T^\dagger = T^\dagger\,T\).

### Key identity: \((T^\top)^\dagger = T^\dagger{}^\top\)

A very standard matrix‐manipulation identity is
\[
  (A^\top)^\dagger \;=\; ( \overline{A^\top} )^{\,\!T} 
  \;=\; \bigl(\overline{A}\bigr)^{T\,T}
  \;=\;\overline{A}
  \quad\text{if \(A\) is real, but in general}\quad
  (A^\top)^\dagger \;=\; \bigl(A^\dagger\bigr)^\top.
\]
For a complex matrix \(T\), it is indeed true that
\[
  (T^\top)^\dagger \;=\; \bigl(T^\dagger\bigr)^\top.
\]
Armed with that, one checks normality of \(T^\top\) via:

- Start with \(T\) normal: \(T T^\dagger = T^\dagger T\).
- Take the transpose of that equality: 
  \[
    (T\,T^\dagger)^\top \;=\; (T^\dagger\,T)^\top,
    \quad\text{i.e.}\quad
    (T^\dagger)^\top\,T^\top 
    \;=\; 
    T^\top\,(T^\dagger)^\top.
  \]
- But \((T^\dagger)^\top = (T^\top)^\dagger\).  So the last identity exactly says 
  \[
    (T^\top)^\dagger\,T^\top \;=\; T^\top\,(T^\top)^\dagger,
  \]
  which is the definition that \(T^\top\) is normal.

Therefore:

> **If \(T\) is normal, then its transpose \(T^\top\) is also normal.**  

In the language of operators on an inner‐product space, being “normal” is equivalent to being unitarily diagonalizable.  Thus if \(T\) is unitarily diagonalizable, so is \(T^\top\).  And since \(T'\) is represented by \(T^\top\), it follows \(T'\) is also unitarily diagonalizable.

---

## Bottom Line

- Algebraically (over any field), \(T\) is diagonalizable if and only if \(T'\) is diagonalizable (they share the same minimal polynomial).
- Over \(\mathbb{C}\) with an inner product, \(T\) is **unitarily** diagonalizable if and only if \(T\) is normal; and it turns out that if \(T\) is normal, then \(T'\) (represented by \(T^\top\)) is also normal.  

**Hence there is _no_ example** of a normal (unitarily diagonalizable) operator \(T\) whose dual \(T'\) fails to be normal (unitarily diagonalizable).  In other words:

> **Whenever \(T\) is unitarily diagonalizable, so is \(T'\).  
> There are no counterexamples.**
